title: [BUG] Product attribute in GFF output can include reserved characters
body:
## Short description of the problem

When using `anvi-get-sequences-for-gene-calls` with the `--export-gff3` flag, attributes in column 9 are sometimes formatted incorrectly.

## anvi'o version

```
Anvi'o .......................................: hope (v7.1)

Profile database .............................: 38
Contigs database .............................: 20
Pan database .................................: 15
Genome data storage ..........................: 7
Auxiliary data storage .......................: 2
Structure database ...........................: 2
Metabolic modules database ...................: 2
tRNA-seq database ............................: 2
```

## System info

OS is Red Hat Enterprise Linux release 8.3 (Ootpa).
Anvi'o is installed as a conda environment.

## Detailed description of the issue

When generating GFF files, Anvi'o currently places any gene annotations in the 'product' attribute in column 9 of the file. Depending on the annotation source, this information may contain large amounts of text, sometimes including non-alphanumeric characters. Some of these characters are reserved in the GFF3 file format, but are not escaped properly in the output from Anvi'o. This can lead to these files being incorrectly parsed by other software.

In the GFF3 file specification (found [here](https://github.com/The-Sequence-Ontology/Specifications/blob/master/gff3.md)), they state that the semicolon, comma, equals sign, and ampersand are reserved in column 9. Many gene annotation sources often contain commas in their annotation data. Also, when referencing PubMed, COG annotations use semicolons to delimit lists with multiple PubMed IDs. The Anvi'o tRNAs annotation source also often uses semicolons (or did the last time I checked).

When creating GFF3 files, Anvi'o should check the data that will be added to attributes in column 9 of the output for these reserved characters and escape them as described in the file specification.

## Files to reproduce

Here is a small contigs database where the COG20_FUNCTION annotations sometimes contain commas and/or semicolons: [Rnf_example.zip](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ur5j25do6kupu6j/Rnf_example.zip?dl=0)

To reproduce, run `anvi-get-sequences-for-gene-calls --export-gff3 -c Rnf_example.db -o Rnf_example.gff` in Anvi'o 7.1 or
`anvi-get-sequences-for-gene-calls --export-gff3 -c Rnf_example.db -o Rnf_example.gff --annotation-source COG20_FUNCTION` in the dev version.

Note the raw commas in the product attribute for many of the genes, and the raw semicolon in the product attribute for gene 8.

title: Ecophylo skip sanity check
body:
This PR is to address #1993

By default the ecophylo workflow will now only sanity check `external-genomes` and `metagenomes` one time. Additionally, the user can now by pass the one time check by switching the `run_genomes_sanity_check` to `false`

title: [BUG] Cannot summarize from the interactive interface
body: ## Short description of the problem Error when trying to summarize a pangenome from the interactive interface (using Chrome). I've seen the error on @arbarno's laptop, during a workshop. ## anvi'o version Anvi'o 7.1 ## System info MacOS Monterey ## Detailed description of the issue The issue only happened when using the interactive interface, not when using `anvi-summarize`. I couldn't reproduce the error on my laptop, even when using the same databases. No idea what's causing the issue, but I felt like reporting it anyway.

title: [BUG] EcoPhylo re-runs sanity checks for every rule on HPC
body:
## anvi'o version

```
$ anvi-self-test --version
Anvi'o .......................................: hope (v7.1-dev)

Profile database .............................: 38
Contigs database .............................: 20
Pan database .................................: 16
Genome data storage ..........................: 7
Auxiliary data storage .......................: 2
Structure database ...........................: 2
Metabolic modules database ...................: 4
tRNA-seq database ............................: 2
```

## Detailed description of the issue

I noticed that straightforward rules from EcoPhylo, e.g. `anvi_run_hmms_hmmsearch` on a singular genome, were taking an unrealistic amount of time to run on the HPC.

Upon further examination, I saw that the log file from an individual job from `anvi_run_hmms_hmmsearch` printed this warning while the rule was running and does not end up in the log file after the rule is complete. (I'm not sure why the log file gets copied over after the rule is complete):

```bash
$ tail -F ECOPHYLO_WORKFLOW/00_LOGS/anvi_run_hmms_hmmsearch-genome.log
# CLUSTERIZE submitted: 2022-10-09 13:01:37.970509
# command: /project2/meren/PEOPLE/mschechter/SCG_workflow_tutorial/.snakemake/tmp.mta5w4bq/snakejob.anvi_run_hmms_hmmsearch.14.sh

HMM profiles .................................: 9 sources have been loaded:
                                                Ribosomal_RNA_16S (3 genes,
                                                domain: None), Ribosomal_RNA_28S
                                                (1 genes, domain: None),
                                                Ribosomal_RNA_18S (1 genes,
                                                domain: None), Protista_83 (83
                                                genes, domain: eukarya),
                                                Ribosomal_RNA_23S (2 genes,
                                                domain: None), Bacteria_71 (71
                                                genes, domain: bacteria),
                                                Archaea_76 (76 genes, domain:
                                                archaea), Ribosomal_RNA_5S (5
                                                genes, domain: None),
                                                Ribosomal_RNA_12S (1 genes,
                                                domain: None)

WARNING
===============================================
We are initiating parameters for the ecophylo workflow


WARNING
===============================================
Some of your genomes (1 of the 3, to be precise) seem to have no functional
annotation. Since this workflow can only use matching functional annotations
across all genomes involved, having even one genome without any functions means
that there will be no matching function across all. Things will continue to
work, but you will have no functions at the end for your gene clusters.
```

These warnings ^ are coming from the EcoPhylo `__init__.py` file. I assumed that this file would only be run ONCE at the beginning of the workflow but I no longer think this is the case.

At least while using `anvi-run-workflow -A --cluster` (haven't found a way to test it locally) it appears that the `Snakefile` runs top to bottom and thus everytime a rule is launched there is a re-initialization [here](https://github.com/merenlab/anvio/blob/master/anvio/workflows/ecophylo/Snakefile#L30-L31). 

Due to this, [MetagenomeDescriptions](https://github.com/merenlab/anvio/blob/master/anvio/genomedescriptions.py#L45) and [GenomeDescriptions](https://github.com/merenlab/anvio/blob/master/anvio/genomedescriptions.py#L45) are re-run for every rule. These methods are used in the EcoPhylo init file to sanity check the incoming `external-genomes.txt` and `metagenomes.txt`. The original idea was that the user should be aware of issues with these files before the workflow begins. However, since this is being re-run for every rule its causing a huge bottleneck, especially when `external-genomes.txt` files have 1000's of genomes.

For now, a simple solution is to give the user to have the option to run sanity checks for `external-genomes.txt` and `metagenomes.txt`. 

I have implemented this in the branch [ecophylo-skip-sanity-check](https://github.com/merenlab/anvio/tree/ecophylo-skip-sanity-check). Simply switch `run_genomes_sanity_check` to false in the config file, and sanity checks for `external-genomes.txt` and `metagenomes.txt` will be skipped.

@ivagljiva this will dramatically speed up large EcoPhylo workflows ^

It would be great if expensive sanity checks could be run outside of anvio snakemake workflow __init__ files since they appear to be re-run for every rule on the cluster.  This would require some refactoring and might be more trouble than it's worth. 

Any suggestions and comments are most welcome :)

title: [BUG] anvi-get-split-coverages doesn't export gene caller ID = 0
body:
## Short description of the problem

anvi-get-split-coverages gives error when gene caller id 0 is given.

## anvi'o version

main on midway :) 

## Detailed description of the issue

When I run the commend:
```bash
anvi-get-split-coverages -p PROFILE.db -c contigs.db --gene-caller-id 0 -o COVs.txt
```

I get this error:
```
Config Error: You must either declare a split or contig name, a bin name in a collection, or a
              gene caller id for this to work.
```

## Files to reproduce
I'll post the files on the Meren lab slack- for some reason I can't upload them here :)

title: check names in lazy init
body: `external-genomes.txt` genome names are not sanity checked during a lazy init. This PR ensures that contigs-db names are checked regardless of lazy or full init.

title: Split cov r v4
body: This PR upgrades `anvi-script-visualize-split-coverages` script to R v4 and addresses #1940.

title: [BUG] Profile.db from anvi-export-locus have wrong info values
body:
## Short description of the problem

When using `anvi-export-locus`, it creates a contigs.db and a profile.db for each locus. Some profile.db info are NoneType (like min_coverage_for_variability: None, instead of 10 by default) which is problematic for downstream summary and maybe other commands. 

## anvi'o version

Github Main

## Detailed description of the issue

When using `anvi-export-locus`, it creates a contigs.db and a profile.db for each locus. I wanted to use `anvi-summarize` so I create a default collection and summarized it. 
I had the following error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/ftrigodet/github/anvio/bin/anvi-summarize", line 122, in <module>
    main(args)
  File "/Users/ftrigodet/github/anvio/bin/anvi-summarize", line 68, in main
    summary.process()
  File "/Users/ftrigodet/github/anvio/anvio/summarizer.py", line 843, in process
    self.init()
  File "/Users/ftrigodet/github/anvio/anvio/summarizer.py", line 800, in init
    ('Min coverage for variability', humanize_n(int(self.p_meta['min_coverage_for_variability']))),
TypeError: int() argument must be a string, a bytes-like object or a number, not 'NoneType'
```

I've compared the db info of a regular profile.db and the one generated by `anvi-export-locus` and noticed that some value are 'None' instead of 0. I'm guessing that's why python is not happy about the 'NoneType'.

Normal profile.db:
```

min_coverage_for_variability .................: 10
report_variability_full ......................: 0
contigs_db_hash ..............................: hash6bee38d8
creation_date ................................: 1656450742.62982
num_splits ...................................: 237
num_contigs ..................................: 51
total_length .................................: 4717681
available_item_orders ........................: tnf-splits:euclidean:ward,tnf:euclidean:ward
items_ordered ................................: 1
default_item_order ...........................: tnf:euclidean:ward
```

`anvi-export-locus` profile.db:
```
DB Info (no touch)
===============================================

## Files to reproduce
Here is a contig.db and blank profile.db for a single genome.
Use the following command to generate the output of `anvi-export-locus`:
```
anvi-export-locus -c CONTIGS.db -s nifH -n 10,10 -O nifH
```
Add a default collection and summarize (it will fail):
```
anvi-script-add-default-collection -c nifH_0001.db -p nifH_0001-PROFILE/PROFILE.db

anvi-summarize -c nifH_0001.db -p nifH_0001-PROFILE/PROFILE.db -C DEFAULT -o nifH-summary
```
[test.tar.gz](https://github.com/merenlab/anvio/files/9005391/test.tar.gz)

title: [BUG] Discrepancy between redundancy estimates
body:
## Short description of the problem

There is a difference in the redundancy estimate between the command `anvi-estimate-genome-completeness` and the report output of `anvi-rename-bins` for an Eukaryote bin. 

## anvi'o version

Development version.


## Detailed description of the issue

I have a collection of bin which contains a large eukaryote. Here is the output of `anvi-estimate-genome-completeness`:
```
Bins in collection "default"
===============================================
╒════════════╤══════════╤══════════════╤════════════════╤════════════════╤══════════════╤════════════════╕
│ bin name   │ domain   │   confidence │   % completion │   % redundancy │   num_splits │   total length │
╞════════════╪══════════╪══════════════╪════════════════╪════════════════╪══════════════╪════════════════╡
│ Bin_1      │ BACTERIA │          0.9 │          98.59 │           8.45 │          530 │        1612349 │
├────────────┼──────────┼──────────────┼────────────────┼────────────────┼──────────────┼────────────────┤
│ Bin_2      │ EUKARYA  │          0.6 │          61.45 │           7.23 │         8411 │       26924911 │
├────────────┼──────────┼──────────────┼────────────────┼────────────────┼──────────────┼────────────────┤
│ Bin_3      │ BLANK    │            1 │              0 │              0 │           62 │         103694 │
├────────────┼──────────┼──────────────┼────────────────┼────────────────┼──────────────┼────────────────┤
│ Bin_4      │ BLANK    │            1 │              0 │              0 │          156 │         378418 │
├────────────┼──────────┼──────────────┼────────────────┼────────────────┼──────────────┼────────────────┤
│ Bin_5      │ BLANK    │            1 │              0 │              0 │           77 │         128382 │
╘════════════╧══════════╧══════════════╧════════════════╧════════════════╧══════════════╧════════════════╛
```

I then used the command `anvi-rename-bins` with the option to specifically rename "bin" into "MAG" based on completeness and redundancy threshold (in this case min 50% complete and max 10% redundancy). Surprisingly, the Eukaryote bin was not renamed as a MAG, and here is the report made by `anvi-rename-bins`:

|**old_bin_name**|**new_bin_name**|**completion**|**redundancy**|**size_in_Mbp**|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|Bin_1|p800_00M_PP_MUC_MAG_00001|98.59|8.45|1.61|
|Bin_2|p800_00M_PP_MUC_Bin_00002|63.16|34.21|26.92|
|Bin_4|p800_00M_PP_MUC_Bin_00003|1.41|0.00|0.38|
|Bin_3|p800_00M_PP_MUC_Bin_00004|0.00|0.00|0.10|
|Bin_5|p800_00M_PP_MUC_Bin_00005|0.00|0.00|0.13|

You can see that the completeness and redundancy don't match the numbers above. Could it be that `anvi-rename-bins` uses a different set of SCG to estimate completeness? 

## Files to reproduce

The eukaryote genome is pretty big, but if needed I can find a way to send it.

title: [BUG] `anvi-profile` does not compute codon variable positions when the ORF length matches the contig length
body:
## Short description of the problem

`anvi-profile` with the flag `--profile-SCVs` does not compute codon variable positions when the ORF length matches the contig length. This is important for the EcoPhylo workflow where individual genes are profiled for SNVs and any other small contig profiling scenario.

## anvi'o version

```
$ anvi-self-test --version

Anvi'o .......................................: hope (v7.1-dev)

Profile database .............................: 38
Contigs database .............................: 20
Pan database .................................: 15
Genome data storage ..........................: 7
Auxiliary data storage .......................: 2
Structure database ...........................: 2
Metabolic modules database ...................: 4
tRNA-seq database ............................: 2
```

## System info

macOS Big Sur

## Files to reproduce

Here are the files to reproduce the problem:

[SCV_test.tar.gz](https://github.com/merenlab/anvio/files/8903176/SCV_test.tar.gz)

```bash
tar -zxvf SCV_test.tar.gz && cd SCV_test

$ tree -L 2
.
├── 00_SAMPLES
│   ├── AUS0002_R1.fastq
│   ├── AUS0002_R2.fastq
│   ├── AUS0004_R1.fastq
│   └── AUS0004_R2.fastq
├── ORF_length
│   ├── 00_LOGS
│   ├── 01_QC
│   ├── 02_FASTA
│   ├── 03_CONTIGS
│   ├── 04_MAPPING
│   ├── 05_ANVIO_PROFILE
│   ├── 06_MERGED
│   ├── Ribosomal_L16-external_gene_calls_subset.tsv
│   ├── Ribosomal_L16-references_for_mapping_NT.fa
│   ├── fasta.txt
│   ├── metagenomics_config.json
│   └── samples.txt
├── ORF_length_longer
│   ├── 00_LOGS
│   ├── 01_QC
│   ├── 02_FASTA
│   ├── 03_CONTIGS
│   ├── 04_MAPPING
│   ├── 05_ANVIO_PROFILE
│   ├── 06_MERGED
│   ├── Ribosomal_L16-references_for_mapping_NT_longer.fa
│   ├── fasta.txt
│   ├── metagenomics_config.json
│   └── samples.txt
└── fasta.txt
```

To create this data, I ran the metagenomics workflow with `anvi-profile --profile-SCVs` in two different scenarios: (1) ORF length = contig length and (2) contig length > ORF length. Big thanks to @FlorianTrigodet for helping me design the reproducible example. 

**ORF length = contig length**

`ORF_length/` contains `Ribosomal_L16-references_for_mapping_NT.fa` where the contig length is equal to the ORF length. To ensure this, I have provided `Ribosomal_L16-external_gene_calls_subset.tsv` with associated amino acid sequences. After running the metagenomics workflow in reference mode this is what I see in the `profile.db`. Please note the sample `AUS0004` did not map reads to the references and thus there is no merged `profile.db`.

```bash
open ORF_length/05_ANVIO_PROFILE/Ribosomal_L16/AUS0002/PROFILE.db
```
Here you see that no codon variability is recorded.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8404575/173670133-fc2b892b-01ff-455d-8b99-4ca8d0098e9e.png)

All SNV positions are recorded as non-coding regions
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8404575/173624168-6b1626df-6184-4a0a-bd11-e58f0fd81a25.png)


**contig length > ORF length**

In this scenario I extended all the sequences in `Ribosomal_L16-references_for_mapping_NT.fa` by running:

```bash
sed 's/$/TTTTT/' Ribosomal_L16-references_for_mapping_NT.fa > Ribosomal_L16-references_for_mapping_NT_longer.fa
```

Additionally, I did not provide an `external-gene-calls.txt` and let prodigal do the gene calling. For the record, I ran the previous scenario without an `external-gene-calls.txt` and got the same results of no codon variability. 

```bash
open ORF_length_longer/05_ANVIO_PROFILE/Ribosomal_L16/AUS0002/PROFILE.db
```

SNVs are now in coding regions and we get codon variability back :)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8404575/173670577-d4490cd4-ce47-4dda-b303-70fdc9ef6a3e.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8404575/173624284-46b1f29b-e439-46f6-ba59-abb5c99cc333.png)

Thank you very much in advance for anyone who can help me fix this :)

title: [BUG] anvi-script-visualize-split-coverages gives error
body:
## Short description of the problem

`anvi-script-visualize-split-coverages` gives this error:
```
Error in contig_offsets[as.character(split_name), as.character(sample_name)] :
  subscript out of bounds
Calls: parse_input_data ... get_offset_snv_positions -> unlist -> Map -> mapply -> <Anonymous>
Execution halted
```

## anvi'o version

anvio main/master

## Detailed description of the issue

Both of these commands (one uses the `sample_data_colors.txt` file and one does not) give the same error.

anvi-script-visualize-split-coverages -i split_cov_USA0006.txt -o USA0006_INSPECT.pdf --sample-data sample_data_colors.txt --snv-data USA0006_SNVs.txt --free-y-scale TRUE --max-coverage 80000 --snv-marker-transparency 0.9 --snv-marker-width 0.1

title: [BUG] anvi-report-inversions has a few issues
body:
## Short description of the problem

The output distance between two palindromes is incorrect. 
Also, the search palindrome command does not handle properly the blast output splitting when there are two mismatches next to each other. 

## anvi'o version

anvio-dev

## Detailed description of the issue

### Compute the distance
Here are the start and stop position of the palindromes and the inversion distance as seen in the output:

first_start | first_end | second_start | second_end | distance
-- | -- | -- | -- | --
557999 | 558021 | 558138 | 558160 | 131
831039 | 831056 | 831183 | 831200 | 144
980099 | 980116 | 980243 | 980260 | 144
1017600 | 1017621 | 1017740 | 1017761 | 131

The distance should be second_start - first_end. Here, some look like the distance was computed between first_start and second_start. And for other like the first one, the distance does not correspond to any start and stop position reported here. Probably some conflict with the blast output splitting changing some positions.

title: Changing anvi-export-locus to use gene index rather than gene-caller-id
body:
Hi Everyone,

I realized my original PR or #1841 was not a robust solution. However, I think I got it. 

This update of `anvi-export-locus` relies on ordering gene-calls of a contig by start position, then any locus exporting functionality is done with the index of the gene positions rather than the gene-caller-id which as we all know is not always in numerical order. 

Looking forward to your thoughts!

Cheers,
Matt

title: sort locus by gene start position
body:
Hey @meren and @ekiefl, please check out this important change I am making to `anvi-export-locus` to address #1841.

Sorting by gene start position will allow for all gene-callers to be considered at once.

Shoutout to @ivagljiva for helping me come up with a solution!

title: [BUG] Contig boundary errors in anvi-export-locus
body:
## Short description of the problem

`anvi-export-locus` sometimes fails to identify when a requested locus crosses a contig boundary.

## anvi'o version

```
Anvi'o .......................................: hope (v7.1)

Profile database .............................: 38
Contigs database .............................: 20
Pan database .................................: 15
Genome data storage ..........................: 7
Auxiliary data storage .......................: 2
Structure database ...........................: 2
Metabolic modules database ...................: 2
tRNA-seq database ............................: 2
```

## System info

OS is Red Hat Enterprise Linux release 8.3 (Ootpa).
Anvi'o is installed as a conda environment.

## Detailed description of the issue

I ran `anvi-export-locus` on several genomes asking for 5 genes on each side of the target, and in several of them the target gene is near the end of a contig. In most of these, Anvio properly trimmed down the gene calls to just those on the correct contig, but in three of them it did not. This manifested in a few different ways down the line.

In two of the problem loci, a contig boundary was only within 5 genes on one side of the target. One of them had the target in the forward direction, and the other had the target in the reverse direction. In these, the eventual failure was creating a gene calls file with negative start and/or stop positions for the genes in the locus, which then caused an error.

In the third problem locus, the target was within 5 genes of a contig boundary on both sides. Anvio properly trimmed the gene calls on one side of the target, but not on the other side. This resulted in a gene calls file with genes from two contigs, and eventually there was an error in utils.get_most_likely_translation_frame because one of the sequences was too short (presumably one of the genes from the wrong contig, as the others all seem fine).

## Files to reproduce

Here is a Dropbox link with the databases, the console output I saw for each one, and the incorrect gene calls files they created. I also included instructions to reproduce.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/q0ht6r0pleo4yni/anvi-export-locus.zip?dl=0

title: [BUG] Handling categorical data layer render slowdown
body:
## issue 

At present, the interactive interface will automatically switch from drawing categorical layer data as colors to drawing text. Currently this decision is based on the number of _unique_ items per layer, with the cutoff being `20`. This makes sense, as rendering 100 different colors for a layer doesn't provide a ton of visual clarity. 

This process does not take into account the total number of items per layer, so a layer with 21 unique items and 1500 total items will require the rendering of 1500 text objects. This is a bottleneck. 

## solution
Setting a threshold for total items per layer allows us to incorporate an additional performance-minded setting
- if _unique_ items per layer < 20, display type defaults to `color`
- if _unique_ items per layer > 20 && total items per layer < 1000 (or any arbitrary cutoff), switch type from `color` to `text`
- if _unique_ items per layer > 20 && total items per layer > 1000, set the layer height to `0` and warn the user that the layer has been minimized for the sake of performance. The user can then opt to display the layer however they see fit.

title: anvi-setup-ncbi-cogs issue
body:
# Latest update to this issue

We now realize that issues with `anvi-setup-ncbi-cogs` are related to your internet speed. Faster internet connections result in successful download of the files. Due to the technical setup of the NCBI servers, slow connections that take a very long time to download files are prematurely cut, resulting in broken files :/

Unfortunately there is nothing anvi'o can do about this unless we copy the NCBI resource and host it elsewhere, but I don't think that is an appropriate thing to do. If you have any comments or suggestions, please share below.


---

The rest of the text in this message is here for historical reasons. Please ignore it.

---

# Why are you here?

Probably anvi'o sent you here so you can help us address this issue.

# Summary

This is a problem we have not been able to address, so we decided to collect more data from people to understand this enigmatic error ([example](https://groups.google.com/g/anvio/c/t-my0SUq4JY/m/tvIOT8-eBAAJ), or these: #1686, #1671, #1647) that usually happens around here in the code while running `anvi-setup-ncbi-cogs`:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):

title: [BUG] Uniform bin name input + display values
body:
## The need

anvi'o currently allows users to set bin names with spaces (ie 'my special bin')
anvi'o currently does an iffy job stripping underscores from bin names when displayed
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62408216/116136621-24593d00-a698-11eb-9be2-739426e500bd.png)

## The solution

strict pattern matching to replace all spaces in user-set bin names with underscores (while also showing the user these changes so they can see the correct naming convention)
strict pattern matching to replace all underscores with spaces when displaying bin names

## Beneficiaries
anyone with an appreciation for standardized naming conventions and prettified display values

title: [BUG] anvi'o splits FASTA files in place by default
body:
## Short description of the problem

The utils function `split_fasta` splits FASTA files by default in the same directory as the input FASTA file. This behavior can cause various problems, one of which was reported by Richard Lawrence on anvi'o Slack. In Richard's case, when users run `anvi-self-test` on one of the computing clusters at Texas A&M, anvi'o tried to write into its source code directory while trying to test multi-threaded prodigal, for which users had no write permission for obvious reasons. The error occurred even when users explicitly specified an output directory for test output files.

## anvi'o version

`v7` and the development branch.

title: Fix hmmer parsing
body:
This PR addresses the bug reported in #1564, in which HMMER parsing was failing in certain cases where the alignment of space-delimited HMMER output files was off in certain lines.  

**Brief description of the bug**
In rows where some of the columns contained shorter text or numbers than the previous rows, the whitespace alignment in raw HMMER output is shitty. Here is one example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10360586/114077015-f046e500-986c-11eb-8d13-cd5625115ca0.png)

Previously, the `anvio.drivers.HMMer` class was pre-processing the HMMER output files to get rid of the 'description' field, because that field internally contains spaces and therefore cannot be directly converted into a tab-delimited format where each row has a consistent number of columns. In edge cases like the one shown above, the attempted removal of the 'description` field itself was producing inconsistent numbers of columns. This was causing `anvi-run-kegg-kofams` as well as `anvi-run-hmms` to fail at the parsing step.

**Brief description of the fix**
The first thing I did was to remove pre-processing from the `anvio.drivers.HMMer.append_to_main_table_file()` function which concatenates raw HMMER output from multiple threads, with the exception of removing header lines (as suggested by @ekiefl in #1670). So now that class does not attempt to remove the description field or convert spaces to tabs, and the parser class receives essentially raw, space-delimited HMMER output, just without the comment lines.

Because we must wait until [HMMER4 is released to have tab-delimited output](https://github.com/EddyRivasLab/hmmer/issues/235) that works nicely with our current parsing implementation, my solution was to add a function to the `anvio.parsers.HMMERTableOutput` class which uses pandas to read the file by splitting on spaces. In the resulting dataframe, the space-containing 'description' field may be split up into multiple columns; we combine up to six of these columns into one 'description' column and then print the dataframe to a new tab-delimited file that can then be parsed as usual. 

**Some considerations**
This solution does produce yet another intermediate, temporary file. Perhaps a more elegant way would be to write a parser from scratch instead of generating a tab-delimited file and then sending that to `get_TAB_delimited_file_as_dictionary()`. But in the hopes that we will eventually get tab-delimited output directly from HMMER, I did it this way to save time at the expense of tmp disk space. I'm happy to change it if anyone has strong opinions against this strategy :)

Special thanks to @michaelkyu and @ekiefl for discussing the speed and memory implications of using pandas with me. I have their assurances that it will be quite fast and efficient. @michaelkyu even wrote a much faster implementation than what I had originally (thanks, Mike!).

I have not been able to test this with `anvi-run-kegg-kofams` on very large metagenomes which yield hundreds of thousands of KOfam hits. I do not anticipate that it will be a problem, but I wanted to explicitly mention it in case I am wrong, so we all have someone to blame if things blow up later. :)

**Testing**
I tested this implementation on genomes that were failing prior to the fix, (as well as a few genomes that were doing fine), and everything worked perfectly. I tested with different numbers of threads, too.

To make sure that my changes don't produce different results from what we were getting before, I took a test genome and compared HMM hits that we get with `master` and with this branch.
```
## git checkout master
anvi-run-hmms -c GCF_000725495.1-contigs.db --tmp-dir HMMS_GCF_000725495.1_MASTER/ --just-do-it -T 1
sqlite3 GCF_000725495.1-contigs.db "select * from hmm_hits" | tr '|' '\t' | cut -f 2- >> GCF_000725495.1_master_HMM_1T
anvi-run-hmms -c GCF_000725495.1-contigs.db --tmp-dir HMMS_GCF_000725495.1_MASTER/ --just-do-it -T 4
sqlite3 GCF_000725495.1-contigs.db "select * from hmm_hits" | tr '|' '\t' | cut -f 2- >> GCF_000725495.1_master_HMM_4T
## git checkout fix_hmmer_parsing
anvi-run-hmms -c GCF_000725495.1-contigs.db --tmp-dir HMMS_GCF_000725495.1_FIXED_2 --just-do-it -T 4
sqlite3 GCF_000725495.1-contigs.db "select * from hmm_hits" | tr '|' '\t' | cut -f 2- >> GCF_000725495.1_fixed_HMM_4T
anvi-run-hmms -c GCF_000725495.1-contigs.db --tmp-dir HMMS_GCF_000725495.1_FIXED_2 --just-do-it -T 1
sqlite3 GCF_000725495.1-contigs.db "select * from hmm_hits" | tr '|' '\t' | cut -f 2- >> GCF_000725495.1_fixed_HMM_1T
```
There were no differences between `master` and this branch, and the only differences between single- and multi-threaded runs on the same branch were two gene calls that swapped their 23S rRNA annotation:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10360586/114085505-140f2880-9877-11eb-87b0-effe00fbb3b5.png)

I did a similar test for KOfams. 
```
## git checkout master
anvi-run-kegg-kofams -c GCA_000007185.1-KOFAM-WORKS-contigs.db -T 4 --just-do-it
sqlite3 GCA_000007185.1-KOFAM-WORKS-contigs.db "select * from gene_functions where source='KOfam'" | tr '|' '\t' | cut -f 2- > GCA_000007185.1_master_KOfam
## git checkout fix_hmmer_parsing
anvi-run-kegg-kofams -c GCA_000007185.1-KOFAM-WORKS-contigs.db -T 4 --just-do-it
sqlite3 GCA_000007185.1-KOFAM-WORKS-contigs.db "select * from gene_functions where source='KOfam'" | tr '|' '\t' | cut -f 2- > GCA_000007185.1_fixed_KOfam
```

And this is the result of the `diff`:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10360586/114086813-ba0f6280-9878-11eb-875b-d308208607a8.png)

As you can see, the differences are due to slight rounding error in the e-values. I don't think it is a problem. :)

title: A lot of improvements to anvi-estimate-metabolism
body:
This PR started due to a feature request for module-specific KO hit matrices, but expanded to a lot of needed improvements to the metabolism codebase, especially for `--matrix-format`. 

It includes the following changes:

## New feature: module specific KO matrices
Now multi-mode `--matrix-format` has an additional parameter: `--module-specific-matrices`. You can pass a comma-separated list of KEGG module numbers to this flag, and then your matrix output will include KO hit matrices for each module in the list. 

For example, 
```
anvi-estimate-metabolism -e input_txt_files/external_genomes.txt \
                                              --matrix-format \
                                              --module-specific-matrices M00001,M00009 \
                                              -O external_genomes
``` 

will produce the output files `external_genomes-M00001_ko_hits-MATRIX.txt` and `external_genomes-M00009_ko_hits-MATRIX.txt` (in addition to the typical output matrices). Here is what `external_genomes-M00001_ko_hits-MATRIX.txt` looks like:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10360586/106369870-954bbb80-631a-11eb-9e80-f6ad39e610ac.png)
So for every KO in the module definition, there will be a row in this matrix indicating how many hits to that KO were annotated in each input sample.

## A new set of functions for matrix generation
Making matrices for multi mode used to be a huge mess, involving like 4-5 functions and hard-to-read pandas dataframe manipulation. It is much simpler now. We have a generic function to write to a matrix, `KeggMetabolismEstimatorMulti.write_stat_to_matrix()`, and a driver function to call this one for each matrix output file, `KeggMetabolismEstimatorMulti.store_metabolism_superdict_multi_matrix_format()`. The code is much more readable and easier to control, as well (IMO), though maybe not as fancy as using pandas. Sorry not sorry. 🐼 

## Matrix output is just better in general
Here is the improvement list:
- now the full completeness score for each module is reported (before, we were rounding to 2 decimal places)
- you can now use `--include-zeros` for matrix output, in which case matrices will include rows of all 0s (this does not affect module-specific KO matrices, which always show all KOs in the module even if some have all 0s)
- The bug for metagenome mode matrix output, detailed in #1658, is now fixed. That means every contig in a metagenome gets its own column in the matrix (instead of one column for the metagenome overall with the wrong data)

## Metabolism estimation function doesn't return huge dictionaries anymore (by default)
`KeggMetabolismEstimator.estimate_metabolism()` used to return huge superdictionaries of metabolism estimation, even after PR #1543 when we changed the code to append this data to long-format files as we got it. Why? Because `--matrix-format` needed them. Well, no longer. 

Now, by default, this function doesn't return anything. You can ask it to return the entire superdictionaries (the previous behavior) if you need it to, using the `return_superdicts=True` parameter. For the `--matrix-format` case, we ask this function to return only a subset of the superdictionaries which we need for matrix generation (using the `return_subset_for_matrix_format=True` parameter). This relies on a new function to make those subsets, which is `KeggMetabolismEstimator.generate_subsets_for_matrix_format()`

I have not tested this on large datasets, but I am 99.35% certain that the memory consumption will go down, resulting in faster runtime and happier clusters.

## A new set of functions to standardize metadata access
For modules, you can now get a metadata dictionary using `KeggContext.get_module_metadata_dictionary()` and for KOs, you can use `KeggContext.get_ko_metadata_dictionary()`. These are used by functions for both long-format output generation and matrix output generation, so that we can access metadata on the fly rather than passing around large dictionaries including this information.

## REALLY IMPORTANT: `modules` mode output now has warnings for missing KOfam profiles
So, there is this problem where sometimes we don't have (or don't use) a KOfam profile for a KO. Usually this is because it doesn't have a bitscore in the ko_list.txt file from KEGG, which means we can't parse out the weak hits, so we don't even try to annotate it. The downstream problem is that any module with this KO can never have a 1.0 completeness score because we never annotate that KO. This was a problem that occurred silently before. 

But now, `modules` mode output includes a "warnings" column (by default) that tells you if the module contains a KO that we cannot annotate. So at least people know about this issue now. 

If the module has a '--' step (no associated KO), we also put a warning that these steps are assumed to be incomplete.

(If you are a Meren Lab member and want more info on this problem, I investigated it [here](https://github.com/merenlab/lab-fiesta/issues/955#issuecomment-743827152).)

## Bonus: re-organization
This doesn't matter to anyone except for me right now, but I've organized functions according to their larger purpose and added comments to section the code. Makes it easier to find the functions you are looking for.

title: [BUG] `anvi-estimate-metabolism --matrix-format` produces incorrect output for metagenome input
body:
## Short description of the problem

Metagenome mode estimates metabolism within each contig separately, but the --matrix-format output is aggregating the estimation results for each contig and reporting them for the metagenome as a whole. Which is very wrong. So I am very sad.

## anvi'o version

`v7` and `v7-dev` 

## Detailed description of the issue

You can run `anvi-estimate-metabolism --matrix-format -M METAGENOMES.TXT` to get three matrix files - one for module completeness, one (binary) for module presence-absence, and one for # of KOfam hits. 

These matrices _should_ have one column for every contig in every metagenome, but instead they have one column for every metagenome. See the following example for module completeness:
```
module	meta_1	meta_2
M00001	0.90	11.01
M00002	1.00	11.77
M00003	0.75	10.98
M00004	1.00	9.36
M00005	1.00	17.00
M00006	1.00	11.8
```
In this example, meta_1 is not actually a metagenome, it is an isolate that I used for quick testing. But meta_2 is a real metagenome, and you can immediately see the problem in that column: completeness scores are larger than 1 (which should never happen), because the module's completeness in each contig is being added together. Not good. The other two matrix outputs suffer from a similar problem.

title: [BUG] anvi-estimate-functional-enrichment does not work with metagenome mode modules output

## anvi'o version

## Detailed description of the issue

Here is the bug we get:

title: Fix KEGG KOfams annotation bug #1644
body: This PR addresses #1644 by splitting the one function that checked and set the modules db hash into two separate functions: the sanity check is called before `hmmsearch` starts running (as before), and now the modules db hash is set after it is done running.

title: [BUG] pandas version issue for anvi-estimate-metabolism --matrix-format
body:
## Short description of the problem

As reported on the anvi'o Slack, users with newer versions of `pandas` may get the following error when running `anvi-estimate-metabolism --matrix-format`:

```
[...]
  File "/home/jcastros/miniconda3/envs/anvio-7/lib/python3.6/site-packages/anvio/kegg.py", line 3250, in store_metabolism_superdict_multi_matrix_format
    matrix = sps.coo_matrix((df[header], (df.index.labels[1], df.index.labels[0]))).todense().tolist()
AttributeError: 'MultiIndex' object has no attribute 'labels'
``` 

The reason this happens is that newer versions of `pandas` do not have `labels` attribute in the `MultiIndex` class.

## anvi'o version

```
Anvi'o .......................................: hope (v7)

Profile database .............................: 35
Contigs database .............................: 20
Pan database .................................: 14
Genome data storage ..........................: 7
Auxiliary data storage .......................: 2
Structure database ...........................: 2
Metabolic modules database ...................: 2
tRNA-seq database ............................: 1
```

The version of `pandas` that I know works (on my system) is 0.25.1
I am not sure in which version the `labels` attribute disappears, but we know it does not work for 1.0.5

## The fix

Need to add an explicit version requirement for `pandas` in the installation setup for anvi'o `v7` 

(Users on `v7` can try downgrading their pandas like so to make it work: `pip install pandas==0.25.1` )

title: Issue 1588: fix --cluster-contigs param in snakemake
body:
This PR resolves #1588, in which 1) we could not set a value of `false` for the `--cluster-contigs` param in `anvi-profile`, and 2) the default behavior was opposite that of the recommendation (ie, clustering was run for single profiles by default, but not for profiles that would need to be merged, which is not what `anvi-profile -h` recommends as @ekiefl pointed out).

The solution to 1) was to accept parameters that are not `None`, and the solution to 2) was to flip the logic so that by default clustering is not run for single profiles, but it was run for samples in groups with more than 1 member. The warning message that prints when you explicitly set `--cluster-contigs` to something has been updated to reflect the new defaults.

**How did I test this?**
The datapack from the [snakemake workflows tutorial](https://merenlab.org/2018/07/09/anvio-snakemake-workflows/#fastatxt) was perfect for this, as it had a simple `fasta.txt` with two references, one of which has two samples mapping to it and one of which has just one sample mapping to it. So right there we have a test case for both merged and single profiles.

I downloaded the datapack, set it up, got a default config file, and did a dry run to see the command lines for `anvi-profile`:
```
anvi-run-workflow -w metagenomics -c config.json -A -n
```
Which, as expected, yielded the correct defaults of `--cluster-contigs` for profiles that would be merged (G02 group) and no clustering for the single profile (G01 group):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10360586/103295003-aff7e100-49b8-11eb-87e2-6bfba480dad1.png)

I then made another config in which I explicitly set the value of `--cluster-contigs` to `false` (this was not working for me before), and this time in the dry run all `anvi-profile` jobs skipped the clustering:
```
anvi-run-workflow -w metagenomics -c config_set_cluster_contigs.json -A -n
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10360586/103295145-f8170380-49b8-11eb-828a-35f9839ee5dd.png)
(I am only showing the first two samples in this screenshot)

Setting the parameter value to `true` provides the opposite behavior, as expected.

title: Issue 1554 - hmmer multithread fix
body:
This PR addresses the issue in #1554 where an exception occurring in one HMMER worker thread did not kill the whole process, resulting in incomplete output. 

As @ekiefl suggested, I copied his approach from `anvi-profile` and converted the HMMER driver class from using threads to using the `multiprocessing` class. Output and exceptions from the worker processes are passed back to the main process using a shared Queue. The main process goes through the Queue to merge the output from all workers and if necessary, terminate all processes when an exception is thrown by a worker. 

I tested that this approach gives us the same output as our current approach in `main`, and it does. Meren Lab members can find the relevant details for that [here](https://github.com/merenlab/lab-fiesta/issues/1223).

body:

  File "/workdir/lab_envs/anvio/lib/python3.6/site-packages/anvio/hmmops.py", line 336, in get_sequences_dict_for_hmm_hits_in_splits
    hmm_hit = self.hmm_hits[split_entry['hmm_hit_entry_id']]
KeyError: 17702
```

He mentioned the following:

> This goes away if I anvi-delete-hmms and run anvi-summarize again, but comes back if I re-run anvi-run-hmms. It always seems to fail on the same bin. So curious! Any ideas?

Switching to the `main` branch did not solve the problem, either. He kindly sent the files through e-mail for me to reproduce this bug. I will document my journey with these data here.

---

I am now looking at these databases, and while I can see at least one thing that is quite wrong here, I can’t figure out how it could have happened without destroying everything else: the information in `collections_info` table is incompatible with the actual data in the concoct collection. When I run the following command,

```
anvi-show-collections-and-bins -p PROFILE.db
```

```
sqlite3 PROFILE.db "select count(distinct(bin_name)) from collections_of_splits where collection_name='concoct'"
159
```

`159 != 103`. It seems, none of the refined bins were updated in the info table. But it is an easy fix, and this actually solves it:

```
anvi-export-collection -p PROFILE.db -C concoct -O concoct-collection
anvi-delete-collection -p PROFILE.db -C concoct
anvi-import-collection concoct-collection.txt -C concoct -c CONTIGS.db -p PROFILE.db
```

When I run the following command now,

```
anvi-show-collections-and-bins -p PROFILE.db
```

I get this, which makes more sense:

```

===============================================

First I created a collection only with this bin to better understand the problem:

```
grep Bin_3_32 concoct-collection.txt  > bin332.txt
anvi-import-collection bin332.txt -p PROFILE.db -c CONTIGS.db -C bin332
```

Everything seems to be working:

Do you see what is unique for `hmm_hit_entry_id` `392`?

Less than half of this gene is in `Ppolionotus_3F_000000007193_split_00105`. The remainder is in `Ppolionotus_3F_000000007193_split_00106`, which is not binned into `Bin_3_32`.

Just for posterity, this is the `hmm_hits` for `Ribosomal_RNA_23S`:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/197307/101851675-9da92680-3b21-11eb-99bd-acc6a324c9ef.png)

PS: removing the `Ribosomal_RNA_23S` solves the issue (obvi) so Jon can move on with his investigation:

```

```

title: [BUG] Cannot set --cluster-contigs to false for anvi-profile in metagenomics workflow
body:
## Short description of the problem

I am trying to produce single profiles without clustering. I have set the `--cluster-contigs` flag to `false` in my config file for the metagenomics workflow, but this flag is still being added to the `anvi-profile` rule. 

## anvi'o version

```
Anvi'o version ...............................: esther (v6.2-master)
Profile DB version ...........................: 35
Contigs DB version ...........................: 20
Pan DB version ...............................: 14
Genome data storage version ..................: 7
Auxiliary data storage version ...............: 2
Structure DB version .........................: 2
Kegg Modules DB version ......................: 2
tRNA-seq DB version ..........................: 1
```

## System info

Midway

## Detailed description of the issue

See screenshots below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10360586/101698506-2f8c3300-3a3f-11eb-9e36-58668e35d074.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10360586/101698557-4cc10180-3a3f-11eb-8889-5d613f44ef17.png)

I believe the issue is in the `get_cluster_contigs_param` function in the `anvio/anvio/workflows/metagenomics/Snakefile` file. The conditional statement will be false if you set `--cluster-contigs` to `false`, so the else clause always runs, and that clause uses the `--cluster-contigs` flag if you are working with single profiles (I am).

title: [BUG] Gene sequences shown in the interface do not match to actual gene sequences
body:
## Short description of the problem

Gene sequence reported in the inspect page buttons is incorrect.

## anvi'o version

Current main.

## Detailed description of the issue

This is what the sequence looks like in the inspect page:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/197307/99926320-eaf65d00-2d06-11eb-9c29-1b48f5756804.png)

This is what you get when you ask for it from the command line:

```
anvi-get-sequences-for-gene-calls -c HIMB083-contigs.db --gene-caller-ids 1504 -o 1504.fa

cat 1504.fa
>1504
GCCCTCGTGGTGAAATTGGTAGACACAAAGGACTTAAAATCCTTGCCGCTTGCGGAGTGCCAGTTCGAGTCTGGCCGAGGGCACCA
```

Both checks out. But when you click this,

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/197307/99926359-09f4ef00-2d07-11eb-8bab-b01031bc73a2.png)

And then click `Get DNA`, this is what you get:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/197307/99926380-1c6f2880-2d07-11eb-9ed0-76258c4ac357.png)

A totally made up sequence 😂 

## Files to reproduce

It should reproduce in any anvi'o project.

@Jessica-Pan discovered this, so I'm pinging her here.

title: [BUG] Multithreading issue with anvi-run-hmms
body:
## Short description of the problem

anvi-run-hmms works well on a contigs database as a single thread, but fails when running in multiple threads.

## anvi'o version

This happens with the main branch.

## Detailed description of the issue

Running it with a **single thread**, everything is fine:

```
anvi-run-hmms -c CONTIGS.db -I Ribosomal_RNA_23S

HMM sources ..................................: Ribosomal_RNA_23S
Alphabet/context target found ................: RNA:CONTIG

HMM Profiling for Ribosomal_RNA_23S
===============================================
(...)

Number of weak hits removed ..................: 0
Number of hits in annotation dict  ...........: 8
Pruned .......................................: 3 out of 8 hits were removed due to redundancy
Gene calls added to db .......................: 5 (from source "Ribosomal_RNA_23S")

✓ anvi-run-hmms took 0:01:47.840152
```

Running it with **multiple threads**:

```
anvi-run-hmms -c CONTIGS.db -T 4 -I Ribosomal_RNA_23S --just-do-it

HMM sources ..................................: Ribosomal_RNA_23S
Alphabet/context target found ................: RNA:CONTIG

HMM Profiling for Ribosomal_RNA_23S
===============================================
(...)
Number of raw hits ...........................: 8

✖ anvi-run-hmms encountered an error after 0:00:45.813513


Config Error: Number of column names declared (15) differs from the number of columns found
              (16) in the matrix
              ('/var/folders/x5/gt4031w53fs63csv1fp0r_3w0000gn/T/tmpe_h6eje3/hmm.table') :/

```

And this is the same file after HMMs were run with **multiple threads**:

```

title: [BUG] anvi-script-visualize-split-coverages cannot make a fill chart using both --xlim flag and a samples.txt
body:
## Short description of the problem

When making a fill chart (the default chart type) with `anvi-script-visualize-split-coverages`, you can either use the `--xlim` flag or a `samples.txt`, but not both at the same time without encountering an error. Adding `--chart-type line` fixes the issue.

## anvi'o version

```
Anvi'o version ...............................: esther (v6.2-master)
Profile DB version ...........................: 34
Contigs DB version ...........................: 18
Pan DB version ...............................: 14
Genome data storage version ..................: 7
Auxiliary data storage version ...............: 2
Structure DB version .........................: 2
Kegg Modules DB version ......................: 2
```

## System info

MacOS Catalina, and I installed anvi'o via the [youre-a-wizard-arry method](http://merenlab.org/2016/06/26/installation-v2/#following-the-active-codebase-youre-a-wizard-arry
) on the anvi'o installation page.

## Detailed description of the issue

When I run this command:
```
anvi-script-visualize-split-coverages -i coverages.txt \
                                      -o coverages.pdf \
                                      -d variability.txt \
                                      -w 30 \
                                      -s samples.txt \
                                      --snv-marker-transparency 1 \
                                      --snv-wobble-pos-color=#749637 \
                                      --snv-non-wobble-pos-color=#e33e33 \
                                      --snv-intergenic-color=#999999 \
                                      --snv-marker-width=0.1 \
                                      --free-y-scale
```
I get the desired output, split and colored according to my specifications in the `samples.txt` file, and no errors.

But when I run this command (adding the --xlim flag):
```
anvi-script-visualize-split-coverages -i coverages.txt \
                                      -o coverages.pdf \
                                      -d variability.txt \
                                      -w 30 \
                                      -s samples.txt \
                                      --snv-marker-transparency 1 \
                                      --snv-wobble-pos-color=#749637 \
                                      --snv-non-wobble-pos-color=#e33e33 \
                                      --snv-intergenic-color=#999999 \
                                      --snv-marker-width=0.1 \
                                      --free-y-scale \
                                      -x 2287,4232
```
I get this output and error message:
```
I, [2020-08-05 17:11:24.720491 #95741] INFO -- Checking options

I, [2020-08-05 17:11:44.002584 #95741] INFO -- Total data points before compression: 4504045
I, [2020-08-05 17:12:05.543009 #95741] INFO -- Total data points after compression: 21840
I, [2020-08-05 17:12:05.543143 #95741] INFO -- Coverage will be capped at 1000
I, [2020-08-05 17:12:05.667414 #95741] INFO -- Sample_data given.  Adjusting split_coverages.
I, [2020-08-05 17:12:05.669567 #95741] INFO -- Not all samples in the split coverages file were present in the sample data file.
W, [2020-08-05 17:12:05.681073 #95741] WARN -- Some of the samples listed in the SNV data file were not also in the split coverages file.  These will not be included in the SNV data.
I, [2020-08-05 17:12:05.724884 #95741] INFO -- Making coverage plots
I, [2020-08-05 17:12:05.830516 #95741] INFO -- Writing coverage plots
Error: Aesthetics must be either length 1 or the same as the data (9): fill
Backtrace:
     █
  1. └─global::write_plot(cov_plot, dat, opts)
  2.   ├─base::print(plt$plot)
  3.   └─ggplot2:::print.ggplot(plt$plot)
  4.     ├─ggplot2::ggplot_build(x)
  5.     └─ggplot2:::ggplot_build.ggplot(x)

  9.             └─ggplot2:::f(..., self = self)

Removed 327 rows containing missing values (position_stack).

Specifying `--chart-type line` fixes the issue, but it would be nice to be able to make a fill chart with these specifications, too. :)

title: [BUG] Problem with R1 and R2 outputs from anvi-get-short-reads-from-bam
body:
## Short description of the problem
When using `anvi-get-short-reads-from-bam`, you can choose between two type of outputs: (1) a single fasta; (2) 3 fasta files for R1, R2 and unpaired reads. The problem with (2) is that one of the paired sequence should be the reverse complement. 

## anvi'o version

```
Anvi'o version ...............................: esther (v6.2-master)
Profile DB version ...........................: 34
Contigs DB version ...........................: 18
Pan DB version ...............................: 14
Genome data storage version ..................: 7
Auxiliary data storage version ...............: 2
Structure DB version .........................: 2
Kegg Modules DB version ......................: 2
```

## Detailed description of the issue

I have used `anvi-get-short-reads-from-bam` with the `-Q` argument to get a separate R1 and R2 fasta file (and unpaired in a third fasta).
At first, I was puzzled by identical sequences found in both R1 and R2 fasta file. I manually checked with the initial short reads used for the mapping and I found out that one read was always good, while the other (could be either R1 or R2) was the reverse complement of the original short reads. 

Let me give you a graphic abstract of what's happening:
```
Initial paired-end short reads:
  R1
------->
========================================   
                                <-------
                                    R2

With anvi-get-short-reads-from-bam:
  R1                               R2
------->                        ------->                
========================================    OR    ========================================
                                                  <-------                        <-------
                                                     R1                               R2
```

My issue with identical sequence both in R1 and R2 only concerned shorter sequence, with no insert. And therefore the reverse complement is the paired read sequence:
```
Original paired-end short reads:
  R1
------->
========
<-------
  R2

With anvi-get-short-reads-from-bam:
  R1         
------->
  R2         
------->                 
========
```

Since I want to assemble these sequences, I need the original paired-end orientation for insert size estimation.

## anvi'o version

## Detailed description of the issue

![too-much-logging-in-the-south-loop](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3172014/87974646-5f3e9c80-ca98-11ea-982a-6d3ae40ffb88.png)

title: anvi-estimate-metabolism and --kegg-data-dir fails with --external-genomes Config Error
body:
Hi! 

Odd little problem. For some reason when I run `anvi-estimate-metabolism --external-genomes external-genomes.txt -O output.txt --kegg-data-dir /PATH/to/DB` I get an error. See below for the error  with `--debug` flag. The odd thing is that I can run the command every other way with `--kegg-data-dir`. For example, using one of the genomes from the `--external-genomes` file works fine like this: `anvi-estimate-metabolism -c _Arcobacter_porcinus_117434-contigs.db  --kegg-data-dir /PATH/to/DB -O output.txt` (INPUT 1). Works with contig.db in metagenome mode (INPUT 1), with a profile.db and a collection/bin (INPUT 2). 

I tried setting path variables before running the command (`KEGG`, `kegg_data_dir`, `kegg_modules_db_path`, `kegg_modules_db`, etc)...No luck. Always defaults back to `data/misc/KEGG`. Although I am not sure this would ever work :) 

The only way I could get it to work was changing line 207 of `kegg.py` from `data/misc/KEGG` to my db path.

 If this is really a bug, sorry I can't offer a real solution :/

title: self-test --suite full fails at "A dry run in 'gene-mode'..."
body:
hello!!

Hope you all are good. I was doing a routine test drive (`anvi-self-test --suite full`) of my anvi'o install (like all good users should do :) and encountered this message. 

```
File/Path Error: Your tree contains names that are composed of only digits (like this one: '21').
                 Sadly, anvi'o is not happy with such names in newick trees or clustering
                 dendrograms :( Anvi'o developers apologize for the inconvenience.

Config Error: According to the exit code ('254'), anvi'o suspects that something may have gone
              wrong while running your tests :/ We hope that the reason is clear to you from
              the lines above. But if you don't see anything obvious, and especially if the
              test ended up running until the end with reasonable looking final results, you
              shouldn't worry too much about this error. Life is short and we all can worry
              just a bit less.
```

Despite anvio's words of encouragement, the reason for the error was not clear to me. I attached the terminal output and what seems to be the offending db. Neither the `items_orders` or the `layer_orders` tables are populated---judging by the way anvio was yelling about newick trees I thought the problem would be there for sure.  In fact only `layer_additional_data` and `gene_level_coverage_stats` have data. Wish I could be more help :)
 
[full_suite.log](https://github.com/merenlab/anvio/files/4755052/full_suite.log)

title: Transfer_RNAs HMM source yields gene with negative start position
body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8688665/76364221-a51d7400-62f2-11ea-82c9-42180fb0d180.png)

Looking at this `genes_in_contigs` table, there is a gene predicted to have a start position that is negative. This breaks `anvi-profile`

It is worrying because to me it suggests such a shift may happen commonly, and that it is only caught in this particular instance, where the shift pushes the gene off the contig.

Tagging you @semiller10 

Until this is fixed, perhaps tRNA should not be run by default? What do you think @meren?

title: Importing functions from eggnog-mapper results in no accession number (accession number stored under EGGNOG_BACT)
body:
```
anvi-self-test -v
Anvi'o version ...............................: esther (v6.1-master)
Profile DB version ...........................: 31
Contigs DB version ...........................: 14
Pan DB version ...............................: 13
Genome data storage version ..................: 6
Auxiliary data storage version ...............: 2
Structure DB version .........................: 1
```
Installed using "Following the active codebase" instructions on a Linux server.  Eggnog-mapper version is 2.0.1 (which as far as I can tell outputs a .emapper.annotations table in the same format as emapper v.2.0.0.  [https://github.com/eggnogdb/eggnog-mapper/wiki/eggNOG-mapper-v2](url))

I noticed this issue when getting the error described in #1322, my annotations from eggnog-mapper aren't associated with accession numbers.  When you import functions from eggnog mapper into Anvi'o using:
```
anvi-script-run-eggnog-mapper \
    -c Gemella_morbillorum_strain_JCVI_4_bin.2.contigs.db \
    -T 16 \
    --annotation Gemella_morbillorum_strain_JCVI_4_bin.2.emapper.fixed.annotations \
    --use-version 2.0.0
```
It appears to work fine, but when you look to see what annotation sources are present:
```
anvi-export-functions -c Gemella_morbillorum_strain_JCVI_4_bin.2.contigs.db -l  -o test1.txt
                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
ANNOTATION SOURCES FOUND
===============================================
* Preferred_Name
* BRITE
* KEGG_MODULE
* COG_FUNCTION
* BiGG_Reactions
* eggNOG_free_text
* KEGG_PATHWAYS
* EC_NUMBER
* eggNOG_best_tax
* COG_CATEGORY
* GO_TERMS
* KEGG_KO
* EGGNOG_BACT
```
'EGGNOG_BACT' is not a column in the emapper.annotations output file, and the value for the 'seed_eggNOG_ortholog' column is getting stored in 'EGGNOG_BACT'.  For example, when you export COG_FUNCTION, you get an accession number and e-value (because getting the ncbi-cogs was independent of the eggnog-mapper):
```
$ anvi-export-functions -c Gemella_morbillorum_strain_JCVI_4_bin.2.contigs.db --annotation-sources COG_FUNCTION  -o test1.txt
Annotation sources ...........................: Preferred_Name, BRITE, KEGG_MODULE, COG_FUNCTION, BiGG_Reactions, eggNOG_free_text, KEGG_PATHWAYS, EC_NUMBER, eggNOG_best_tax, COG_CATEGORY, GO_TERMS, KEGG_KO, EGGNOG_BACT.
Requested sources ............................: COG_FUNCTION.
Number of annotations reported ...............: 1,177                                                                                                                                                                       
Output file ..................................: test1.txt
$ head test1.txt 
gene_callers_id source  accession       function        e_value
2       COG_FUNCTION    COG0554 Glycerol kinase 5.7e-228
5       COG_FUNCTION    COG3022 Cytoplasmic iron level regulating protein YaaA, DUF328/UPF0246 family   2e-53
6       COG_FUNCTION    COG1853 NADH-FMN oxidoreductase RutF, flavin reductase (DIM6/NTAB) family       9.5e-22
7       COG_FUNCTION    COG0587 DNA polymerase III, alpha subunit       1e-176
8       COG_FUNCTION    COG0205 6-phosphofructokinase   6.9e-118
9       COG_FUNCTION    COG0469!!!COG3848       Pyruvate kinase!!!Phosphohistidine swiveling domain of PEP-utilizing enzymes    1.6e-166
10      COG_FUNCTION    COG1052 Lactate dehydrogenase or related 2-hydroxyacid dehydrogenase    4.5e-88
11      COG_FUNCTION    COG0640 DNA-binding transcriptional regulator, ArsR family      4.6e-27
12      COG_FUNCTION    COG5658!!!COG5658       Uncharacterized membrane protein!!!Uncharacterized membrane protein     3.9e-13
```
BUT, when you export any of the annotations from eggnog, you get a blank accession number and no e_value:
```
$ anvi-export-functions -c Gemella_morbillorum_strain_JCVI_4_bin.2.contigs.db --annotation-sources KEGG_KO  -o test2.txt
Annotation sources ...........................: Preferred_Name, BRITE, KEGG_MODULE, COG_FUNCTION, BiGG_Reactions, eggNOG_free_text, KEGG_PATHWAYS, EC_NUMBER, eggNOG_best_tax, COG_CATEGORY, GO_TERMS, KEGG_KO, EGGNOG_BACT.
Requested sources ............................: KEGG_KO.
Number of annotations reported ...............: 1,022                                                                                                                                                                       
Output file ..................................: test2.txt
$ head test2.txt 
gene_callers_id source  accession       function        e_value
2       KEGG_KO         ko:K00864       0
5       KEGG_KO         ko:K09861       0
7       KEGG_KO         ko:K02337       0
8       KEGG_KO         ko:K00850       0
9       KEGG_KO         ko:K00873, ko:K00958    0
10      KEGG_KO         ko:K03778       0
13      KEGG_KO         ko:K02003, ko:K02004, ko:K05685 0
15      KEGG_KO         ko:K01297, ko:K01485, ko:K01487, ko:K01563, ko:K04075, ko:K11991        0
16      KEGG_KO         ko:K00563, ko:K00571, ko:K07319, ko:K18896      0
```
This is true for most of the annotation sources from eggnog except EGGNOG_BACT, where you now get accession numbers (the seed_eggNOG_ortholog) and e_values, and for some reason the functions are from the column called 'KEGG_rclass' in the eggNOG output (which is not one of the annotation sources Anvi'o recognizes, according to the list above):
```
$ anvi-export-functions -c Gemella_morbillorum_strain_JCVI_4_bin.2.contigs.db --annotation-sources EGGNOG_BACT  -o test3.txt
Annotation sources ...........................: Preferred_Name, BRITE, KEGG_MODULE, COG_FUNCTION, BiGG_Reactions, eggNOG_free_text, KEGG_PATHWAYS, EC_NUMBER, eggNOG_best_tax, COG_CATEGORY, GO_TERMS, KEGG_KO, EGGNOG_BACT.
Requested sources ............................: EGGNOG_BACT.
Number of annotations reported ...............: 1,264                                                                                                                                                                       
Output file ..................................: test3.txt
$ head test3.txt 
gene_callers_id source  accession       function        e_value
1       EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01180         1.1e-72
2       EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01178 RC00002,RC00017 9.3e-286
5       EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01175         3.2e-122
6       EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01174         6.5e-110
7       EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01173 RC02795 0
8       EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01172 RC00002,RC00017 9.5e-175
9       EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01171 RC00002,RC00015,RC02809,RC02889 1.3e-263
10      EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01170 RC00044 6.6e-187
11      EGGNOG_BACT     562982.HMPREF0432_01169         7.1e-43
```
It seems to me like Anvi'o should be associating these accession numbers and e_values with all of the annotation sources provided by emapper, not just 'EGGNOG_BACT', which isn't actually a column in the emapper.annotation file.  This would also seem to be the source of the error described in #1322  and #1320 ...this is why those annotation sources have no accession numbers and give the error described in those issues.  I have attached (in a zipped folder) the original contigs file used to make the contigs.db, the contigs.db itself, and the two versions of the emapper.annotations output file. The 'raw' version is the untouched output from emapper, the 'fixed' version has been treated with `sed -e '/^#/!s/^/g/'` to add a 'g' to the gene number make Anvi'o happy.  Let me know if you need anything else.  Thanks!

[anvio_files.zip](https://github.com/merenlab/anvio/files/4200574/anvio_files.zip)

title: One of the commits from 2/5 or 2/6 appears to break anvi-pan-genome
body:
Hey guys,
I'm new to the community, so if I'm not following protocol with my posts, let me know!  I noticed this issue today so I figured I would report it.

```
anvi-self-test -v
Anvi'o version ...............................: esther (v6.1-master)
Profile DB version ...........................: 31
Contigs DB version ...........................: 14
Pan DB version ...............................: 13
Genome data storage version ..................: 6
Auxiliary data storage version ...............: 2
Structure DB version .........................: 1
```
Installed on Linux server using 'Following the active codebase' (wizard status!)

One of the commits from either 2/5/20 or 2/6/20 appears to make problems for `anvi-pan-genome`.  Either running `anvi-pan-genome` on actual data or `anti-self-test --suite pangenomics` now causes an error each time anvi'o gets to the computing homogeneity step.  The below error is from `anvi-self-test --suite pangenomics`:

```
* Gene clusters are initialized for all 121 gene clusters in the database.

[06 Feb 20 18:17:25 Computing gene cluster homogeneity indices] Initializing 1 threads...                                                                                         ETA: ∞:∞:∞
WARNING
==============================================================
Homogeneity indices computation for gene cluster GC_00000101 failed. This can
happen due to one of three reasons: (1) this gene cluster is named incorrectly,
does not exist in the database, or is formatted into the input dictionary
incorrectly, (2) there is an alignment mistake in the gene cluster, and not all
genes are aligned to be the same lenght; or (3) the homogeneity calculator was
initialized incorrectly. As you can see, this is a rare circumstance, and anvi'o
will set this gene cluster's homogeneity indices to `-1` so things can move on,
but we highly recommend you to take a look at your data to make sure you are
satisfied with your analysis.

Process Process-4:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/projdata/0718/projects/jon/conda_envs/github/anvio/anvio/dbops.py", line 1165, in homogeneity_worker
    funct_index, geo_index, combined_index = homogeneity_calculator.get_homogeneity_dicts(gene_cluster)
  File "/usr/local/projdata/0718/projects/jon/conda_envs/github/anvio/anvio/homogeneityindex.py", line 174, in get_homogeneity_dicts
    fun = self.compute_functional_index(cluster_sequences)
  File "/usr/local/projdata/0718/projects/jon/conda_envs/github/anvio/anvio/homogeneityindex.py", line 61, in compute_functional_index
    elif utils.is_amino_acid_functionally_conserved(amino_acid_residue_1,amino_acid_residue_2):
  File "/usr/local/projdata/0718/projects/jon/conda_envs/github/anvio/anvio/utils.py", line 1564, in is_amino_acid_functionally_conserved
    if amino_acid_residue_2 in conserved_group:
TypeError: argument of type 'NoneType' is not iterable

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/projdata/0718/projects/jon/conda_envs/envs/anvio-master/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/process.py", line 258, in _bootstrap
    self.run()
  File "/usr/local/projdata/0718/projects/jon/conda_envs/envs/anvio-master/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/process.py", line 93, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/projdata/0718/projects/jon/conda_envs/github/anvio/anvio/dbops.py", line 1176, in homogeneity_worker
    combined_index[gene_cluster_name] = -1
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'combined_index' referenced before assignment
```
..and the program stalls here

You get the same issue when running `anvi-pan-genome`.
Going back to before those commits via `git checkout 6f99da878519fe9879fa8f190413949a62498231` restores proper completion of `ansi-self-test --suite pangenomics`

title: anvi-run-workflow ignores --external-gene-calls in config.json
body:
On master, the external genes file parameter supplied in the `config.json` is not respected in `anvi-run-workflow -w contigs`. Here is the `config.json`:

```
{
    "workflow_name": "contigs",
    "fasta_txt": "fasta_chimera_test.txt",
    "anvi_gen_contigs_database": {
        "--project-name": "{group}",
        "--description": "",
        "--skip-gene-calling": "",
        "--external-gene-calls": "10_GENOME_CLUSTER_PANGENOMES/{group}/CHIMERA/gene_calls.txt",
        "--ignore-internal-stop-codons": true,
        "--skip-mindful-splitting": "",
        "--contigs-fasta": "",
        "--split-length": "",
        "--kmer-size": "",
        "--prodigal-translation-table": "",
        "threads": ""
    },
    "output_dirs": {
        "CONTIGS_DIR": "00_DELETE",
        "LOGS_DIR": "00_DELETE2"
    },
    "config_version": "1"
}
```

And here is one of the commands submitted by snakemake:

```
[Sun Jan  5 21:02:36 2020]
rule anvi_gen_contigs_database:
    input: 10_GENOME_CLUSTER_PANGENOMES/cluster_000002/CHIMERA/chimeric_genome.fa
    output: 00_DELETE/cluster_000002-contigs.db
    log: 00_DELETE2/cluster_000002-anvi_gen_contigs_database.log
    jobid: 4
    wildcards: group=cluster_000002
    resources: nodes=1
anvi-gen-contigs-database -f 10_GENOME_CLUSTER_PANGENOMES/cluster_000001/CHIMERA/chimeric_genome.fa -o 00_DELETE/cluster_000001-contigs.db   --project-name cluster_000001   --ignore-internal-stop-codons     >> 00_DELETE2/cluster_000001-anvi_gen_contigs_database.log 2>&1
```

You can see that the `--external-gene-calls` parameter is never passed to snakemake.

Script for reproducing can be found on merenlab #github channel.

title: Collection doesn't really store in manual mode
body:
Is that on purpose?

This is what I see:

```
* Collection sources has been requested (info dict with 0 item(s) has been returned).
* A request to store 5 bins that describe 134 splits under the collection id "default" has been made.
```

But then when I load the interactive next time then there is no collection.

I marked this as a bug, because if we don't want to allow for collections to be stored in manual mode then we should explicitly do so. Or better yet, we can allow for it :-)
